title: 109_hr4291
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protection Against Executive Compensation Abuse Act" and includes additional disclosures on executive compensation. The "Protection Against Executive Compensation Abuse Act" amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require issuers to disclose comprehensive statements of their compensation plans for principal executive officers in annual reports and proxy materials. The "Protection Against Executive Compensation Abuse Act" amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require issuers to disclose comprehensive statements of their compensation plans for principal executive officers, including details of any type of compensation paid or to be paid, estimates of pension value and other benefits, and agreements related to compensation. The issuer must disclose performance measures used for executive compensation and shareholder approval is required for compensation plans. When an acquisition, merger, consolidation, or sale of assets is proposed, the person soliciting proxies must disclose any agreements with executive officers regarding compensation related to the transaction. The proxy solicitation material must include this information in a clear and simple form as per SEC regulations. The SEC requires proxy solicitation material to disclose any executive officer agreements related to acquisitions or mergers. Additionally, the Commission mandates issuers to adopt a policy for reimbursement of certain compensation received by executive officers under specific conditions. The SEC mandates disclosure of executive officer agreements related to acquisitions or mergers and requires issuers to adopt a policy for reimbursement of certain compensation received by executive officers under specific conditions. The term 'principal executive officer' includes individuals serving as the chief executive officer of an issuer during the most recent fiscal year, regardless of compensation level, and the two most highly compensated executive officers for issuers with total assets between $250,000,000 and $500,000,000. The Securities and Exchange Commission must issue final rules and regulations within one year of the enactment of this Act regarding the disclosure of executive officer compensation for issuers with assets over $500,000,000. SEC. 3. CLEAR AND SIMPLE INTERNET DISCLOSURE. Amends Section 16(a)(4) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require statements to be presented in a clear, simple, and readily accessible format.
